case_name: Criminal Writ Petitions Nos. 2 to 10 of 1966

facts.text: Nine criminal Writ Petitions Nos. 2 to 10 of 1966 filed under Article 22 and 226 of the Constitution of India and section 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure

anchor.surface_text: 1 . In each of these nine criminal Writ Petitions  Nos. 2 to 10 of 1966  under Article 22 and 226 of the Constitution of India and under section 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure,

facts.text: Petitioners pray for writ of habeas corpus to produce them in court and set at liberty if no lawful authority for detention

anchor.surface_text: the petitioner therein prays that this companyrt may be pleased to issue a writ of habeas companypus calling upon the respondents to produce him Court and to show on what authority they have detained him and, if they fail to show lawful authority for doing so, to set him at liberty.

facts.text: Facts of the nine cases are more or less identical and common questions of law arise, so consolidated

anchor.surface_text: The facts of these cases are more or less identical. Common questions of law arise for decision in these petitions. Hence they are companysolidated together.

facts.text: Ugly incidents in Delhi on 7th of this month (November 1966)

anchor.surface_text: After the ugly incidents in Delhi on 7th of this month, the petitioner were arrested between the 7th and 13 of this month.

facts.text: Petitioners arrested between 7th and 13th of November 1966

anchor.surface_text: After the ugly incidents in Delhi on 7th of this month, the petitioner were arrested between the 7th and 13 of this month.

facts.text: Petitioners are now detained in prison

anchor.surface_text: They are number detained in prison.

facts.text: Petitioners allege they were not informed when arrested and not produced before any Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: They allege that they were number informed whey they were arrested, number were they produced before any Magistrate Their case is that they are unlawfully detained.

facts.text: Respondents claim petitioners arrested under Section 107 read with section 151 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: The case for the respondents is that the petitioners were arrested under Section 197 read with section 151 of the Code. Thereafter they were produced before one or the other f the magistrates in Delhi,

facts.text: Respondents claim petitioners produced before magistrates in Delhi who ordered release on bail but failed to give security so ordered to judicial custody

anchor.surface_text: who had ordered them to be released on bail, but as they failed to give the security ordered, they had been ordered to be kept in judicial custody.

facts.text: Police officers who arrested petitioners filed affidavits stating arrest under section 107 read with 151 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: The police officers, who arrested the petitioners have filed affidavits in these case. According to them , arrested the petitioners under section 107 read with section 151 of the companye.

facts.text: Magistrates who ordered detention filed affidavits stating petitioners produced before them, directed release on bail on furnishing security, failed so remanded to judicial custody

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrates, who are said to have ordered their detention, have also filed their affidavits, in these cases. In their affidavits they say that when the petitioners were produced before them, they have directed their release on bail on their furnishing security, as ordered, but as they failed to furnish, security, they have been remanded to judicial custody

facts.text: Shri Bhim Singh, Inspector Police, arrested Shri Balraj Madhok (petitioner in WP No.2/1966) on 9th November 1966

anchor.surface_text: Shri Bhim Singh, Inspector Police, who arrested Shri Balarj Madhok, the petitioner in Writ Petition No. 2 of 1966 had stated thus in his affidavit. That on 9th November, 1966, I arrested Shri Balraj Madhok, the petitioner,

facts.text: Shri Bhim Singh arrested Amrit Lal s/o Shri Lackhman dass, Mela Ram s/o Ladha Ram and Ram Saroop s/o Mangal Sain, residents of New Rajinder Nagar, New Delhi on 9th November 1966 under S 107/151 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: and Sarvashri Amrit Lal son of Shri Lackhman dass, mela Ram son of Ladha Ram and Ram Saroop son of mangal sain, all residents of new Rajinder nagar, new Delhi under S 107/151 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, on apprehension of imminent danger of breach of peace from then and informed them the reason for their arrest.

facts.text: Reason for arrest: apprehension of imminent danger of breach of peace

anchor.surface_text: on apprehension of imminent danger of breach of peace from then and informed them the reason for their arrest.

facts.text: On 9th November 1966, Sarvashri Balraj Madhok, Amrit Lal, Mela Ram Kapoor and Prof. Ram Saroop produced before Shri N.K. Garg by Rajinder Nagar Police Delhi under police custody with complaint u/s 107/151 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: That on 9th November, 1966, Sarvashri Balraj Madhok, Amrit Lal, Mela ram Kapoor and Prof. Ram Sarrop were produced before me by Rajinder nagar, Police Delhi, under police custody together with a companyplaint under sections 107/151 of the Code of Criminal Procedure against them.

facts.text: Magistrate Shri N.K. Garg apprised the four persons they had been arrested under section 107/151 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: That the said Sarvashri Balraj Madhok, Amrit Lal, Mela Ram Kapoor and Prof. Ram Sarrop were apprised by me that they had been arrested. Under section 107/151 of the companye of Criminal Procedure.

facts.text: Shri N.K. Garg ordered the four to be released on furnishing two sureties of Rs.10,000/- each with personal bond of like amount, failing which remanded to judicial custody till 19th November 1966

anchor.surface_text: That I passed the order that all the four respondents be released on their furnishing two sureties of Rs.10,000/- each with a personal bond of like amount failing which they be remanded to judicial custody till 19th November, 1966.

facts.text: Shri Mela Ram offered sureties of Rs.10,000/- each before Shri R.K. Anand, magistrate 1st Class, Delhi on 10th November 1966 and was released

anchor.surface_text: That out of the four persons, Shri Mela ram offered, to sureties of Rs. 10,000/- each before Shri R.K. Anand, magistrate 1st Class, Delhi on 10th November, 1966 and was released.

facts.text: Shri Balraj Madhok and other two did not produce surety and were remanded to judicial custody till 19th November 1966

anchor.surface_text: That Shri Balraj Madhok and other two respondents did number produce any surety as ordered by me and on their failure to produce the required surety they were remanded to judicial custody till 19th November, 1966

facts.text: Court finds arrests of petitioners not in accordance with law under Section 151 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: From whichever angle we see, it is clear that the arrests of the petitioner were number in accordance with law.

facts.text: Court finds detention of petitioners not in accordance with law because no order under Section 112 CrPC was made

anchor.surface_text: Now I companye to the question whether their detention is in accordance with law. ... Without such an order the Magistrate is incompetent to take further action.

facts.text: Petitioners allege they were never produced before any Magistrate, no Magistrate informed them of offence, no orders passed in their presence

anchor.surface_text: In these cases the petitioners allegations is that they were never produced before any Magistrate numberMagistrate informed them of the offence with which they were charged number were any orders passed in their presence or to their knowledge.

facts.text: Petitions allowed and petitioners directed to be set at liberty forthwith

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons, mentioned above, these petitions are allowed and the petitioners, are directed to be set at liberty forthwith.

holdings.text: the arrests of the petitioner were not in accordance with law

anchor.surface_text: From whichever angle we see, it is clear that the arrests of the petitioner were number in accordance with law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reason for arrest was apprehension of imminent danger of breach of peace, not knowledge of design to commit cognizable offence required by S.151 CrPC; S.107 is preventive measure, not offence as defined in S.4 CrPC; sufficient time available to obtain Magistrate's order.

holdings.text: arrest under Section 151 of the Code could not have been made for the aforementioned reason

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether any arrest under Section 151 of the Code, companyld have been made for the aforementioned reason. That section says A police officer knowing of a design of companymit any

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.151 requires police officer knowing of design to commit cognizable offence that cannot otherwise be prevented; apprehension or possibility insufficient; strict compliance needed as it affects personal liberty.

holdings.text: their detention is not in accordance with law

anchor.surface_text: Now I companye to the question whether their detention is in accordance with law. ... Without such an order the Magistrate is incompetent to take further action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arrests themselves unlawful; additionally, no order under S.112 CrPC made, rendering Magistrate incompetent for further action including remand to custody.

holdings.text: the procedure adopted by the Magistrates is not in accordance with the provisions contained in Chapter Viii of the code

anchor.surface_text: 8 . Now I have to see whether the procedure adopted by the Magistrates is in accordance with the provisions companytained in Chapter Viii of the companye Sub-section  1  of section 107 says- 107.  1  Whenever a

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chapter VIII requires Magistrate to first make written S.112 order as condition precedent before any inquiry, bond order, bail, or remand under S.113,114,117(3); no such order made or shown; agrees with counsel and follows Allahabad HC in Sharon Kumar Gupta requiring strict sequence.

holdings.text: An order under section 112 is the very basis of a proceeding under the chapter. Without such an order the Magistrate is incompetent to take further action.

anchor.surface_text: An order under section 112 is the very basis of a proceeding under the chapter. Without such an order the Magistrate is incompetent to take further action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of Chapter VIII provisions shows S.112 order mandatory before S.117 interim measures or detention; no bail concept in S.107 proceedings.

holdings.text: these petitions are allowed and the petitioners are directed to be set at liberty forthwith

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons, mentioned above, these petitions are allowed and the petitioners, are directed to be set at liberty forthwith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of unlawful arrests and invalid detention procedure under CrPC.

precedents.citation: Sharon Kumar Gupta v Supdt., District Jai, Mathura

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection, I may respectfully quote with approval some of the observations of the Allahabad High Court in Sharon Kumar Gupta v Supdt., District Jai, Mathura, . This is what Bharagava J. Seaking for the Court observed in that case-The point that we have to companysider then is what power the sub-Divisional Magistrate of Chhata had to direct the detention of these detenus in jail.

precedents.case_name: Sharon Kumar Gupta v Supdt., District Jail, Mathura
precedents.cited_proposition: In proceedings under Section 107 CrPC, the Magistrate must first make a written order under Section 112 before remanding persons to custody under Section 117(3)
precedents.cited_holding: Until he had done so, his powers of remanding the detenus to custody under sub-section 3 of section 117 of the Code of Criminal Procedure did not vest in him and could not be exercised by him even if any order under section 112 of the Code had not been prepared by him earlier
